description: Apparently a variation of sprent or sprint.

adjectives.description: sprunt (comparative more sprunt, superlative most sprunt)

examples: "As for that little sprunt piece of the Brain which they call the Conarion..."

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A sudden movement; a leap or jump. [17th–19th c.]

verbs.description: sprunt (third-person singular simple present sprunts, present participle sprunting, simple past and past participle sprunted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, chiefly regional) To make quick or convulsive movements; to start, to jump. [17th–20th c.]
examples: They acted a Tragedy at Padua when I was there last June 1786 I think: the Actors struggled & bounced, and sprunted as if in Convulsions  […] .

entries.meaning: (Scotland, now rare) To make romantic advances to; to flirt. [from 19th c.]
